titleInfo.title: McKinley High School Oral History Project: Old South Baton Rouge Social Organizations
titleInfo.subTitle: Nona Mae Dumouil Gray oral history interview, 2005

name.description: Nona Gray was born in 1916 to Henry Dumouil and Beulah Watson Dumouil. She grew up in Beauregard Town, a neighborhood just south of downtown Baton Rouge. Gray attended Reddy Street School and graduated from McKinley High School in 1932. She received her undergraduate degree from Southern University in 1936, and completed her Master's Degree in Education at Louisiana State University in 1954. At the time she attended LSU, she was one of only four African-Americans in the graduate school. Gray married in 1947 and taught at Perkins Road School, McKinley High and Valley Park School until her retirement in 1977.

subject.topic: Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical College--Graduate students.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Gray discusses growing up in Beauregard Town, a racially-mixed neighborhood, in the 1920s, 30s and 40s. She lists her family members who all lived on the same block that her grandfather, Levanski, had purchased from a French family. She recalls the geography of the neighborhood and surrounding areas: downtown Baton Rouge, the riverfront, Catfish Town, and South Baton Rouge. She talks about stores, restaurants, theaters, churches and businesses in the area. She recounts her time at Reddy Street School and McKinley High, and her experience as one of the first African American graduate students at LSU in the 1950s. She discusses race relations in Beauregard Town and Baton Rouge in the 1920s through 1950s.
